Communities of learners wishing to talk and think together about philosophical issues. These learners are groups of children and adults in formal and informal learning environments including schools, universities, workplaces, residential homes, clubs, community groups, museums, galleries, hospitals, prisons, outdoor or public spaces and events such as conferences and festivals We also work with recent philosophy graduates, philosophy postgraduates and early career researchers offering them alternative, constructive ways to make use of their philosophical training The benefits to individuals are three fold: firstly the skills associated with philosophising help people think and communicate their thinking more clearly Clear thought, clearly communicated benefits individuals in their learning and their life, it also benefits the communites within which they live and learn it 1s not just the skills of philosophy that are beneficial, our work also presents learners with the problems of philosophy, helping them connect with the history of ideas and identify and explore the phitosophical problems that interest them and connect meaningfully with their lives Finally people participating in communal philosophical enquiry report a great deal of enjoyment and satisfaction We make space by facilitating group dialogue, training, mentoring and supporting new facilitators of philosophical enquiry, Initiating, managing and evaluating
